articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Campaign Stumbles as It Tries to Go Big
articles.snippet: The limits of the presumptive Republican nominee’s managerial style, reliant on his gut and built around his unpredictable personality, are becoming apparent.
articles.abstract: The limits of the presumptive Republican nominee’s managerial style, reliant on his gut and built around his unpredictable personality, are becoming apparent.
articles.lead_paragraph: BISMARCK, N.D. — A constant stream of changes and scuffles are unsettling Donald J. Trump’s campaign team, including the abrupt dismissal this week of his national political director.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Verizon and Unions Reach an Agreement That May End Strike
articles.snippet: The accord, after a walkout by nearly 40,000 workers that begin in mid-April, is said to include two key concessions by the company.
articles.abstract: The accord, after a walkout by nearly 40,000 workers that begin in mid-April, is said to include two key concessions by the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Verizon reached an agreement in principle on Friday on a four-year contract with two unions representing nearly 40,000 workers who had been striking since April 13.

articles.headline: Yellen Says Fed on Track to Raise Rates ‘in Coming Months’
articles.snippet: The Fed chief said evidence of a rebound was mounting, but did not suggest that a June rate increase was a foregone conclusion.
articles.abstract: The Fed chief said evidence of a rebound was mounting, but did not suggest that a June rate increase was a foregone conclusion.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Friday that the Fed was on track to raise its benchmark interest rate “in the coming months,” reinforcing a recent effort by central bank officials to prepare investors for higher borrowing costs.

articles.headline: Tech Titans Raise Their Guard, Pushing Back Against News Media
articles.snippet: The leaders of Silicon Valley are becoming more cautious and elusive, even as their products make the world more transparent.
articles.abstract: The leaders of Silicon Valley are becoming more cautious and elusive, even as their products make the world more transparent.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After the news that one of Silicon Valley’s stars secretly funded a lawsuit to bring down a gossip site, the overwhelming response in the tech community has been: More power to him.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Tech Companies Take Their Legislative Concerns to the States
articles.snippet: As they create increasingly sophisticated voice and face recognition products, technology firms are lobbying state lawmakers to discourage restrictive new laws that critics call necessary to prevent the violation of user rights.
articles.abstract: As they create increasingly sophisticated voice and face recognition products, technology firms are lobbying state lawmakers to discourage restrictive new laws that critics call necessary to prevent the violation of user rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Biometric Information Privacy Act of Illinois is not a law many are familiar with. But if you have ever shared a photo on social media, the little-known statute turns out to be one of the nation’s toughest regulations for how companies like Facebook and Google can use facial recognition technologies to identify you online.

articles.headline: Venezuela Drifts Into New Territory: Hunger, Blackouts and Government Shutdown
articles.snippet: The country is adjusting to a new normal of closed government and business offices, food shortages and cuts in water, electricity and phone service.
articles.abstract: The country is adjusting to a new normal of closed government and business offices, food shortages and cuts in water, electricity and phone service.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The courts? Closed most days. The bureau to start a business? Same thing. The public defender’s office? That’s been converted into a food bank for government employees.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey and Patricia Torres

articles.headline: One of the World’s Greatest Art Collections Hides Behind This Fence
articles.snippet: The superrich have stashed millions of works in tax-free storage. So what does that mean for the art?
articles.abstract: The superrich have stashed millions of works in tax-free storage. So what does that mean for the art?
articles.lead_paragraph: The drab free port zone near the Geneva city center, a compound of blocky gray and vanilla warehouses surrounded by train tracks, roads and a barbed-wire fence, looks like the kind of place where beauty goes to die. But within its walls, crated or sealed cheek by jowl in cramped storage vaults, are more than a million of some of the most exquisite artworks ever made.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Doreen Carvajal

articles.headline: Iran-Led Push to Retake Falluja From ISIS Worries U.S.
articles.snippet: An operation to oust the Islamic State from a stronghold in Iraq raises concerns that it could feed the same sectarian tensions that have let militants flourish there.
articles.abstract: An operation to oust the Islamic State from a stronghold in Iraq raises concerns that it could feed the same sectarian tensions that have let militants flourish there.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — American commandos are on the front lines in Syria in a new push toward the Islamic State’s de facto capital in Raqqa, but in Iraq it is an entirely different story: Iran, not the United States, has become the face of an operation to retake the jihadist stronghold of Falluja from the militant group.

articles.headline: Rise of Donald Trump Tracks Growing Debate Over Global Fascism
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s campaign has engendered impassioned discussion about the nature of his appeal and warnings from critics on the left and the right.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s campaign has engendered impassioned discussion about the nature of his appeal and warnings from critics on the left and the right.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The comparison was inflammatory, to say the least. Former Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts equated Donald J. Trump’s immigration plan with Kristallnacht, the night of horror in 1938 when rampaging Nazis smashed Jewish homes and businesses in Germany and killed scores of Jews.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Struggles to Find Footing in Unusual Race
articles.snippet: Anxiety is spreading among Democrats that Mrs. Clinton has yet to find her footing, and that her campaign is still unsure how to combat Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: Anxiety is spreading among Democrats that Mrs. Clinton has yet to find her footing, and that her campaign is still unsure how to combat Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats could hardly believe their good fortune last month when it became clear that Hillary Clinton was headed to a general election showdown with Donald J. Trump. Mr. Trump carried so much baggage and had insulted so many voting blocs that some Clinton supporters began to imagine a landslide.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick, Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Three Days, 700 Deaths on Mediterranean as Migrant Crisis Flares
articles.snippet: Europe was again confronted with the horrors of its refugee crisis during a deadly three-day stretch on the sea, which is becoming a more popular migrant route.
articles.abstract: Europe was again confronted with the horrors of its refugee crisis during a deadly three-day stretch on the sea, which is becoming a more popular migrant route.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — The migrant ships kept sinking. First came a battered, blue-decked vessel that flipped over on Wednesday as terrified migrants plunged into the Mediterranean Sea. The next day, a flimsy craft capsized with hundreds of people aboard. And on Friday, still another boat sank into the deceptively placid waters of the Mediterranean.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Gaia Pianigiani

articles.headline: Governments Turn to Commercial Spyware to Intimidate Dissidents
articles.snippet: Surveillance and hacking tools are becoming increasingly popular among a wide range of nations, many of which use the methods to monitor, silence and punish their critics.
articles.abstract: Surveillance and hacking tools are becoming increasingly popular among a wide range of nations, many of which use the methods to monitor, silence and punish their critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the last five years, Ahmed Mansoor, a human rights activist in the United Arab Emirates, has been jailed and fired from his job, along with having his passport confiscated, his car stolen, his email hacked, his location tracked and his bank account robbed of $140,000. He has also been beaten, twice, in the same week.

articles.headline: In the Hamptons, a Small-Town Paper Is a Beacon in the Mayhem
articles.snippet: The East Hampton Star is a 131-year testament to the central role that local, family-owned newspapers can still play.
articles.abstract: The East Hampton Star is a 131-year testament to the central role that local, family-owned newspapers can still play.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — When the leaves return to the trees outside David Rattray’s office window at The East Hampton Star, it means only one thing: “The beginning of the mayhem.”

articles.headline: Middle Eastern Writers Find Refuge in the Dystopian Novel
articles.snippet: A new wave of bleak, post-revolutionary fiction is emerging from writers grappling with the chaotic aftermath and stinging disappointments of the Arab Spring.
articles.abstract: A new wave of bleak, post-revolutionary fiction is emerging from writers grappling with the chaotic aftermath and stinging disappointments of the Arab Spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: Basma Abdel Aziz was walking in downtown Cairo one morning when she saw a long line of people standing in front of a closed government building.

articles.headline: Product Recalls Rise With Better Detection and Fewer Suppliers
articles.snippet: Better detection tools and stricter safety rules mean that problems that once went undetected are now more often spotted and traced back to their source.
articles.abstract: Better detection tools and stricter safety rules mean that problems that once went undetected are now more often spotted and traced back to their source.
articles.lead_paragraph: Frozen peas that could make you sick. A water heater that might explode. Cars with steering wheels that were prone to fail and cause a crash.

articles.headline: Success of Jerry Brown, and California, Offers Lesson to National Democrats
articles.snippet: Blending elements of Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton, the governor has forged a style of leadership that has brought legislative focus and party unity.
articles.abstract: Blending elements of Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton, the governor has forged a style of leadership that has brought legislative focus and party unity.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — When Bernie Sanders held a rally at an outdoor stadium here the other night, more than 15,000 people turned out in a display of cheering, chanting, singing and cartwheels.

articles.headline: Gawker Case Calls Attention to a Go-To Hollywood Lawyer
articles.snippet: Until Hulk Hogan’s successful suit against Gawker Media, Charles J. Harder was mainly known for defending the privacy rights of Hollywood celebrities.
articles.abstract: Until Hulk Hogan’s successful suit against Gawker Media, Charles J. Harder was mainly known for defending the privacy rights of Hollywood celebrities.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In Hollywood, everyone knows the go-to lawyers.

articles.headline: Can Donald Trump Win? These Battleground Regions Will Decide
articles.snippet: In the four regions likely to decide the presidency — Florida, the upper Southeast, the Rust Belt and the interior West — Mr. Trump faces daunting obstacles.
articles.abstract: In the four regions likely to decide the presidency — Florida, the upper Southeast, the Rust Belt and the interior West — Mr. Trump faces daunting obstacles.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump pulling even or ahead of Hillary Clinton in a series of recent national polls, the once unthinkable has become at least plausible. But if he is to be elected the 45th president, he must compete on a political map that, for now, looks forbidding.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns, Trip Gabriel and Fernanda Santos

articles.headline: Verizon Strike to End as Both Sides Claim Victories on Key Points
articles.snippet: Verizon retreated on some major points and gained tools for paring down its work force in the tentative pact reached with unions representing nearly 40,000 striking workers.
articles.abstract: Verizon retreated on some major points and gained tools for paring down its work force in the tentative pact reached with unions representing nearly 40,000 striking workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Verizon reached a series of tentative agreements with unions representing nearly 40,000 striking workers over the holiday weekend, retreating on some of the major points of contention, including pension cuts and greater flexibility to outsource work.

articles.headline: Effort to Expose Russia’s ‘Troll Army’ Draws Vicious Retaliation
articles.snippet: Finland is an active front in an online “information war” between Russia and the West. When a journalist there confronted pro-Putin agitators, she became a target.
articles.abstract: Finland is an active front in an online “information war” between Russia and the West. When a journalist there confronted pro-Putin agitators, she became a target.
articles.lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — Seeking to shine some light into the dark world of Internet trolls, a journalist with Finland’s national broadcaster asked members of her audience to share their experience of encounters with Russia’s “troll army,” a raucous and often venomous force of online agitators.
